revised_title: Cognitive Effects of Frontal-Lobe Lesions in Humans
tldr: This study examines the cognitive effects of frontal-lobe lesions in humans, specifically focusing on the voluntary control of saccadic eye movements, conditional associative-learning tasks, and the temporal organization of behavior. The research reveals that frontal-lobe lesions can cause impairments in tasks involving motor differentiation, oculomotor control, and the monitoring of temporal sequences of events. The left frontal lobe appears to play a major role in planning and programming voluntary actions, while the right frontal lobe is more involved in monitoring the temporal sequence of externally ordered events.
